title-group.article-title: Intra-Articular Osteoid Osteoma of the First Metatarsal

article-meta.aff: 1Foot and Ankle Unit, Hospital Clinic, Universitat de Barcelona, Barcelona, Spain
2Orthopaedic Department, Hospital Universitari Mutua de Terrassa, Terrassa, Spain
3Histopathology Department, Hospital Universitari Mutua de Terrassa, Terrassa, Spain

author-notes.corresp: Jordi Asunción, Hospital Clínic, Universidad de Barcelona, Foot and Ankle Unit, Orthopedic Surgery Department, Passeig Pitort 30, 08860-Castelldefels (Barcelona), Spain Email: asuncion@clinic.ub.es

body.p: Level of Evidence: V, expert opinion.

Osteoid osteoma (OO) is a solitary benign bone-forming tumor, which accounts for approximately 10% of all benign bone tumors.8 Although most publications attribute the first report to Jaffe in 1935,3,13 Bergstrand was probably the first to describe two cases, in 1930.16,25,29 OO appears most commonly between the second and third decades of life, usually in men.16,23,25 The most frequent location is in the cortical region of the diaphysis of long bones (especially the femur, tibia, and humerus), mainly in the lower limbs. The foot is only rarely involved.27 In a review of a series of 860 cases of OO, Jackson found an incidence of less than 4% in the foot and of 1.7% in the metatarsals.12

The typical clinical presentation is severe pain, in spite of the small size of the tumor. This pain is predominantly nocturnal and typically remits with anti-inflammatory drugs;16 there is usually an increase in local temperature.14 If the lesion is superficial there may also be slight local swelling, which may raise the suspicion of an infection.9,24

The typical radiographic image when the tumor affects the cortical region shows a hypodense hypervascular focal area, or nidus, usually less than 1 cm in diameter, surrounded by a thickening of the cortical region of the reactive bone.

Atypical location and clinical symptoms may hinder diagnosis. Shereff et al reported that this tumor is often located in the cancellous bone, or in the subperiosteal region in the small bones of the foot.23 In these cases x-ray will not produce the standard image; in many cases the cortical reinforcement limiting the nidus is missing.24,26 Moreover, when the OO is intra-articular, the symptoms may include arthritis as the tumor may cause inflammation of the synovium, thus adding the range of inflammatory joint diseases to the differential diagnosis and complicating clinical diagnosis even further.7,24,25,27,29

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 26-year-old woman consulted for pain in the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the right foot over 7 months, with no previous history of trauma. The patient presented with swelling and slightly increased local temperature and painful limitation of joint mobility. The pain was worse at night, but remitted partially with oral anti-inflammatory drugs. Local palpation exacerbated the pain. There were no neurovascular disorders in the limb, and laboratory parameters were within normal limits.

Plain x-ray (Figure 1) showed a lytic lesion of about 4 mm in diameter on the dorsal side of the first metatarsal head. Bone scintigraphy with technetium-99 (Figure 2) revealed a nonspecific focal increase in isotope uptake, located in the dorsal area of the first metatarsal head, which may have corresponded to an arthropathic process or even to a stress fracture. This picture was confirmed on CT (Figure 3), which detected an osteolytic lesion less than 1 cm in the first metatarsal head, with a sclerotic central area surrounded by a faint sclerotic rim, suggesting an osteoid osteoma. The lesion extended to the articular cartilage at the back of the metatarsal head.

caption.p: Posterior-anterior (A) and oblique (B) x-ray imaging of the right forefoot, showing an intra-articular subperiosteal osteolytic lesion in the dorsal side of the first metatarsal head.
Bone scan with technetium-99 with increased uptake located in the dorsal region of the first metatarsal head of the right foot.

Preoperative CT of the first metatarsal head: axial (A), coronal (B), and sagittal view (C), showing the osteolytic nidus of the tumor with central calcification surrounded by a slight sclerotic halo: the standard image of osteoid osteoma.

sec.p: Due to poor pain control, the patient underwent surgery. A dorso-medial incision was made over the metatarsophalangeal joint of the hallux. The area of the lesion was located, revealing a brownish area below the dorsal articular cartilage (Figure 4). The tumor was marked with a Kirschner wire (Figure 5a), which was inserted 1 cm deep under fluoroscopic control, and an en bloc excision of the tumor was performed using cannulated trephines (Figures 5b-c). The cavity was then filled with a cancellous autograft from the ipsilateral tibial metaphysis (Figure 5d). During surgery, it was confirmed that the OO had affected the articular cartilage, but only its dorsal part, with the rest of the joint surface uninvolved.

caption.p: Intraoperative image of the dorsal region of the first metatarsal head showing a brownish area below the articular cartilage corresponding to the osteoid osteoma.

Surgical images: (A) location of the lesion with a Kirschner guide wire, (B) complete tumor resection using a bone trephine, (C) bone defect in the metatarsal head after resection, and (D) autograft with a bone cylinder from the ipsilateral tibial metaphysis.

sec.p: Cylinder bone extracted from the metatarsal head with the nidus inside was sent to the histopathology department for study (Figure 6). Histologic evaluation with hematoxylin-eosin staining revealed a bone fragment with a hypercellular central area (“nidus”) without atypical cells, with vascularized, fibrosclerotic stroma mixed with osteoid tissue, and surrounding the nidus, areas with thickened trabeculae with osteoblastic rims (Figure 7), confirming the diagnosis of osteoid osteoma.

caption.p: Cylinder extracted from the metatarsal head, showing the nidus inside.
Histological image of the lesion. (A) Hipercellular and hypervascular Z central area (nidus). (B) Osteoid tissue. (C) Osteoblastic border.

sec.p: The patient began weightbearing immediately after surgery with postoperative flat-soled shoe. After 3 weeks of immobilization, the patient began rehabilitation with marked improvement of joint mobility. The pain remitted immediately after surgery, and signs of bone graft integration were seen after 6 weeks (Figure 8). After 5 years of follow-up, the patient is asymptomatic with no signs of joint degeneration or any evidence of tumor recurrence (Figure 9).

caption.p: Images 2 months after surgery. (A) Dorsum of foot with surgical scar, postoperative posterior-anterior x-ray (B) and oblique x-ray (C) with complete resolution of the lesion and bone graft integration.
Posterior-anterior (A) and oblique (B) final x-rays 5 years after surgery.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Osteoid osteoma in the bones of the foot is a rare event, with an incidence ranging between 2% and 10%.12,27 The talus bone is the most commonly involved,3,23,24 but the calcaneus, cuboid, navicular, and phalanges2,6,11,12,14,23,25,26,28 and even the cuneiform bones may be affected.2,4,20

Involvement of the metatarsals is even less common, but there have been reports of involvement of the head and neck of the first metatarsal,26,29 the second metatarsal shaft,5,9 base of second metatarsal,17,26 the fourth metatarsal shaft,21 and head and neck of the fifth metatarsal.1,27 With regard to the great toe, phalangeal involvement has been reported in the proximal phalanx of the hallux, with involvement of the interphalangeal joint14 and in the distal phalanx.10,19,22

Although the most common localization is the cortical region of the long bones, in the small bones of the foot the localization is usually cancellous or subperiosteal.23 In the series of 197 cases of osteoid osteoma published by Szendroi, 10% presented with an intra-articular location, most in the hip joint; only 1 case was located in the first metatarsal head.29

When the localization is intra-articular, the clinical and radiologic findings differ from those of the classical osteoid osteoma. In these cases, joint symptoms predominate, such as synovitis, joint effusion, and decreased joint mobility,7,16,25,27 and may simulate and mimic other diseases. When located in the distal phalanx of the fingers, bulging and local swelling may cause the appearance of clubbed fingers, which, together with the increase in temperature and sensitivity and vasomotor disturbances such as hyperhydrosis, can cause confusion with an infectious process, but in these cases there is no increase in C-reactive protein.6,10,16,19,28 When the location is metatarsal there may be clinical symptoms of metatarsalgia, resembling a stress fracture.5 For all these reasons, OO in the foot may remain undiagnosed and treatment may well be delayed.

Radiographically, as has been described elsewhere,7,8 the presence and thickness of the sclerotic ring is less noticeable when the location is intra- or juxta-articular, which may further complicate diagnosis. OO in the bones of the foot does not usually present the typical ring-like x-ray images, and many changes may be seen, including generalized osteoporosis of the foot, an area of homogeneous or heterogeneous opacity without a clear halo, sclerotic cortical thickening with periosteal reaction, or a periosteal reaction surrounded by a geode.2 Moreover, in many cases these radiological manifestations may be slow to appear.

A nontypical clinical picture and an x-ray image that does little to guide the differential diagnosis may be present. Nor is the bone scan particularly informative; a CT scan is needed to help with the definitive diagnosis, showing in many cases the contrast between the nidus and the normal trabecular tissue surrounding it, in the absence of a sclerotic rim.7,29 MRI may aid diagnosis, but it is usually less valuable than CT and the image may be confused with a malignant proliferative process or osteomyelitis due to the presence of edema of the cancellous bone.16,26,29 Definitive diagnosis must always be based on histologic study of the surgical specimen.

Surgical resection of the tumor is the treatment of choice and normally resolves symptoms. Recurrence occurs only if the resection of the nidus is incomplete. The nidus can be detected intraoperatively by a CT,15 or by the tetracycline fluorescence test of the osteoid and peroperative visualization under ultraviolet light,2 allowing precise location of the nidus, avoiding a wide resection of the bone, which might require internal fixation.

Increasingly, noninvasive techniques are used in the treatment of these tumors, such as radiofrequency or thermocoagulation. Their results are similar to those obtained in open surgery,16 though the disadvantage is that they do not provide a definitive histologic diagnosis.

In this case, we opted for en bloc resection using trephines because of the location of the tumor and the ease of surgical access, and also because this approach allowed us to explore the articular cartilage. In cases in which joint involvement is significant or when resection causes joint instability, simultaneous OO resection and arthrodesis of the affected joint may be necessary.2,14 The use of bone trephines allows simple and precise en bloc resection, which is relatively nonaggressive and maintains the bone structural stability due to the small amount of bone excision.15,18

The filling of the cavity with bone graft may be necessary in some cases, especially when small cancellous bones are affected or in intra-articular locations as in this case,17,19 but synthetic bone can also be used.9

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The bones of the foot are an unusual localization for osteoid osteoma, especially intra-articular, but this entity should be considered as a possible diagnosis in cases of pain in the foot without associated etiology—especially in younger patients—in order to avoid delays in diagnosis and in the definitive treatment of the lesion.
